elements.content: A three-dimensional magnetic material [{CoII(pyrimidine)(H2O)}2{CoII(H2O)2}{WV(CN)8}2](pyrimidine)2· 2H2O is prepared. This compound exhibits a charge-transfer-induced spin transition with a large thermal hysteresis loop of 90 K. Irradiating with light causes the low-temperature phase to exhibit a spontaneous magnetization with a Curie temperature of 40 K and a magnetic hysteresis loop with a coercive field of 12 000 G, which is the highest value reported for a photomagnet. The observed photoinduced magnetization is due to the charge-transfer phase transition from the {CoII hs (S = 3/2)}{CoIII ls (S = 0)}2−NC−{WIV(S = 0)}2 phase to the {CoII hs (S = 3/2)}3−NC−{WV(S = 1/2)}2 phase by the irradiation.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional magnetic material [{CoII(pyrimidine)(H2O)}2{CoII(H2O)2}{WV(CN)8}2](pyrimidine)2⋅ 2H2O is prepared. This compound exhibits a charge-transfer-induced spin transition with a large thermal hysteresis loop of 90 K. Irradiating with light causes the low-temperature phase to exhibit a spontaneous magnetization with a Curie temperature of 40 K and a magnetic hysteresis loop with a coercive field of 12000 G, which is the highest value reported for a photomagnet. The observed photoinduced magnetization is due to the charge-transfer phase transition from the {CoII  hs (S = 3/2)}{CoIII  ls (S = 0)}2-NC-{WIV(S = 0)}2 phase to the {CoII  hs (S = 3/2)}3-NC-{WV(S = 1/2)}2 phase by the irradiation.

elements.content: Optical functionality is an attractive issue in the field of molecule-based magnets. Photomagnetism has been observed in the photoinduced magnetization of cobalt−hexacyanoferrate, copper−octacyanomolybdate, etc. It has also been observed in the photodemagnetization of iron−hexacyanochromate and rubidium−manganese−hexacyanoferrate and in the photoinduced magnetic pole inversion of iron−manganese−hexacyanochromate. One possible method for achieving optical control of spontaneous magnetization is to change the electron spin state of a magnetic material. For example, when irradiating changes the oxidation numbers of transition metal ions in a magnetic material, its magnetization varies. From these viewpoints, octacyanometalate-based magnets are useful systems for preparing photomagnetic materials because octacyanometalates can adopt various valence states, such as WIV and WV. In this paper, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, magnetic properties, and photofunctionality of a new type of three-dimensional Co−W bimetallic assembly, CoII 3[WV(CN)8]2(pyrimidine)4·6H2O. This compound exhibits a photoinduced magnetization with a high Curie temperature (T C) of 40 K and a large coercive field (H c) of 12 000 G.
elements.clean_text: Optical functionality is an attractive issue in the field of molecule-based magnets. Photomagnetism has been observed in the photoinduced magnetization of cobalt-hexacyanoferrate, copper-octacyanomolybdate, etc. It has also been observed in the photodemagnetization of iron-hexacyanochromate and rubidium-manganese-hexacyanoferrate and in the photoinduced magnetic pole inversion of iron-manganese-hexacyanochromate. One possible method for achieving optical control of spontaneous magnetization is to change the electron spin state of a magnetic material. For example, when irradiating changes the oxidation numbers of transition metal ions in a magnetic material, its magnetization varies. From these viewpoints, octacyanometalate-based magnets are useful systems for preparing photomagnetic materials because octacyanometalates can adopt various valence states, such as WIV and WV. In this paper, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, magnetic properties, and photofunctionality of a new type of three-dimensional Co-W bimetallic assembly, CoII 3[WV(CN)8]2(pyrimidine)4⋅6H2O. This compound exhibits a photoinduced magnetization with a high Curie temperature (T C) of 40 K and a large coercive field (H c) of 12000 G.

elements.content: The target compound was prepared by adding a 2.5 cm3 aqueous solution of CsI 3[WV(CN)8]·2H2O (0.258 g) to a 2.5 cm3 mixed aqueous solution of CoIICl2·6H2O (0.112 g) and pyrimidine (0.050 g). The precipitated red powder was filtered and washed with water and then dried in air. A single crystal for X-ray structural analysis was prepared by a diffusion method in an H-shaped tube. Elemental analyses by inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy and standard microanalytical methods confirmed that the formula of the compound is [{CoII(pyrimidine)(H2O)}2{CoII(H2O)2}{WV(CN)8}2](pyrimidine)2·2H2O. Calcd:  Co, 12.73; W, 26.46; C, 27.67; H, 2.03; N, 24.20%. Found:  Co, 12.55; W, 26.44; C, 27.75; H, 1.92; N, 24.48%.
elements.clean_text: The target compound was prepared by adding a 2.5 cm3 aqueous solution of CsI 3[WV(CN)8]⋅2H2O (0.258 g) to a 2.5 cm3 mixed aqueous solution of CoIICl2⋅6H2O (0.112 g) and pyrimidine (0.050 g). The precipitated red powder was filtered and washed with water and then dried in air. A single crystal for X-ray structural analysis was prepared by a diffusion method in an H-shaped tube. Elemental analyses by inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy and standard microanalytical methods confirmed that the formula of the compound is [{CoII(pyrimidine)(H2O)}2{CoII(H2O)2}{WV(CN)8}2](pyrimidine)2⋅2H2O. Calcd: Co, 12.73; W, 26.46; C, 27.67; H, 2.03; N, 24.20%. Found: Co, 12.55; W, 26.44; C, 27.75; H, 1.92; N, 24.48%.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis showed that the unit cell consists of four [W(CN)8]3- anions, four [Co1(pyrimidine)(H2O)]2+ cations, two [Co2(H2O)2]2+ cations, four zeolitic waters, and four noncoordinated pyrimidines (Figure a). The coordination geometries of the Co (Co1 and Co2) and W sites are pseudo-octahedron (D 4 h ) and bicapped trigonal prism (C 2 v ), respectively (Supporting Information). The four equatorial positions of Co1 are occupied by cyanide nitrogen atoms of [W(CN)8], while the apical positions are occupied by one nitrogen atom of the pyrimidine and one oxygen atom of the water ligand. Co2 is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms of [W(CN)8], two oxygen atoms of the water ligands, and two nitrogen atoms of the pyrimidines. The five CN groups of [W(CN)8] are bridged to four Co1 and one Co2, and the other three CN groups are free. The coordinated pyrimidine molecules bridge Co1 and Co2. The cyano-bridged Co1−W layers along the ab plane are linked by Co2. Noncoordinated pyrimidine molecules are located between the Co1−W grid layers.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis showed that the unit cell consists of four [W(CN)8]3- anions, four [Co1(pyrimidine)(H2O)]2+ cations, two [Co2(H2O)2]2+ cations, four zeolitic waters, and four noncoordinated pyrimidines (Figure a). The coordination geometries of the Co (Co1 and Co2) and W sites are pseudo-octahedron (D 4  h ) and bicapped trigonal prism (C 2  v ), respectively (Supporting Information). The four equatorial positions of Co1 are occupied by cyanide nitrogen atoms of [W(CN)8], while the apical positions are occupied by one nitrogen atom of the pyrimidine and one oxygen atom of the water ligand. Co2 is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms of [W(CN)8], two oxygen atoms of the water ligands, and two nitrogen atoms of the pyrimidines. The five CN groups of [W(CN)8] are bridged to four Co1 and one Co2, and the other three CN groups are free. The coordinated pyrimidine molecules bridge Co1 and Co2. The cyano-bridged Co1-W layers along the ab plane are linked by Co2. Noncoordinated pyrimidine molecules are located between the Co1-W grid layers.

elements.content: (a) The unit cell of [{CoII(pyrimidine)(H2O)}2{CoII(H2O)2}{WV(CN)8}2](pyrimidine)2·2H2O at room temperature. Red, blue, gray, green, and pink ellipsoids represent Co, W, C, N, and O, respectively. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at a 50% probability level. H atoms and zeolitic waters are omitted for clarity. (b) χM T−T plots at 5000 G.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The unit cell of [{CoII(pyrimidine)(H2O)}2{CoII(H2O)2}{WV(CN)8}2](pyrimidine)2⋅2H2O at room temperature. Red, blue, gray, green, and pink ellipsoids represent Co, W, C, N, and O, respectively. Displacement ellipsoids are drawn at a 50% probability level. H atoms and zeolitic waters are omitted for clarity. (b) χM T-T plots at 5000 G.

elements.content: Figure b shows the product of the molar magnetic susceptibility (χM) and temperature (T) versus T plots. The χM T value decreases at 208 K (= T 1/2 ↓) as the sample is cooled at a cooling rate of −1.0 K min-1. Conversely, as the sample is warmed, the χM T value increases around 298 K (= T 1/2 ↑) and returns to the initial value. The thermal hysteresis value (ΔT ≡ T 1/2 ↑ − T 1/2 ↓) is a surprisingly large (90 K). The thermal phase transition changes the CN stretching peaks of [W(CN)8] (νW - CN) in the IR spectra, that is, νW - CN = 2185, 2182, 2171, and 2160 cm-1 at 300 K → νW - CN = 2196, 2166, 2161, 2143, 2128, and 2119 cm-1 at 150 K (Supporting Information). The observed νW - CN peaks at low temperature suggest that the valence state of the W ion is four.
elements.clean_text: Figure b shows the product of the molar magnetic susceptibility (χM) and temperature (T) versus T plots. The χM T value decreases at 208 K (= T 1/2 ↓) as the sample is cooled at a cooling rate of -1.0 K min-1. Conversely, as the sample is warmed, the χM T value increases around 298 K (= T 1/2 ↑) and returns to the initial value. The thermal hysteresis value (ΔT ≡ T 1/2 ↑ - T 1/2 ↓) is a surprisingly large (90 K). The thermal phase transition changes the CN stretching peaks of [W(CN)8] (νW - CN) in the IR spectra, that is, νW - CN = 2185, 2182, 2171, and 2160 cm-1 at 300 K → νW - CN = 2196, 2166, 2161, 2143, 2128, and 2119 cm-1 at 150 K (Supporting Information). The observed νW - CN peaks at low temperature suggest that the valence state of the W ion is four.

elements.content: The results of χM T − T plots and temperature dependence of IR spectra indicate that the observed temperature-induced phase transition from the high-temperature (HT) phase to the low-temperature (LT) phase is due to the electronic state change from CoII hs (S = 3/2)−WV(S = 1/2) to CoIII ls (S = 0)−WIV(S = 0), where hs and ls are high-spin and low-spin states, respectively. Due to the stoichiometric limitation, 1/3 of the cobalt ions should remain as CoII hs , and thus the LT phase is expressed as (CoII hs )(CoIII ls )2[WIV(CN)8]2(pyrimidine)4·6H2O.
elements.clean_text: The results of χM T - T plots and temperature dependence of IR spectra indicate that the observed temperature-induced phase transition from the high-temperature (HT) phase to the low-temperature (LT) phase is due to the electronic state change from CoII  hs (S = 3/2)-WV(S = 1/2) to CoIII  ls (S = 0)-WIV(S = 0), where hs and ls are high-spin and low-spin states, respectively. Due to the stoichiometric limitation, 1/3 of the cobalt ions should remain as CoII  hs , and thus the LT phase is expressed as (CoII  hs )(CoIII  ls )2[WIV(CN)8]2(pyrimidine)4⋅6H2O.

elements.content: The photomagnetic effect on the LT phase was investigated using a SQUID magnetometer. The powder-form sample was spread on a commercial transparent adhesive tape and placed on the edge of an optical fiber. Since the LT phase possesses an intervalence-transfer (IT) band between CoIII−WIV and CoII−WV in the region of 600−1100 nm (λmax = 770 nm) (Supporting Information), a continuous-wave diode laser of 840 nm was used as the light source (50 mW/cm2). Figure a shows the field-cooled magnetization curves before and after irradiating for 160 min at 5 K in an external magnetic field of 10 G. The irradiated sample exhibits a spontaneous magnetization with a T C of 40 K. The magnetization versus external magnetic field plots after irradiating for 120 min show a magnetic hysteresis loop with a H c of 12 000 G at 2 K (Figure b). The magnetization value at 5 T is 7.2 μB, which suggests that CoII and WV ferromagnetically interact. The photoinduced magnetization persists for at least 1 day after turning off the light. The photoinduced magnetization relaxes to the initial value upon a thermal treatment up to 150 K, indicating that the magnetization can be increased by irradiating with light and recovered with a thermal treatment.
elements.clean_text: The photomagnetic effect on the LT phase was investigated using a SQUID magnetometer. The powder-form sample was spread on a commercial transparent adhesive tape and placed on the edge of an optical fiber. Since the LT phase possesses an intervalence-transfer (IT) band between CoIII-WIV and CoII-WV in the region of 600-1100 nm (λmax = 770 nm) (Supporting Information), a continuous-wave diode laser of 840 nm was used as the light source (50 mW/cm2). Figure a shows the field-cooled magnetization curves before and after irradiating for 160 min at 5 K in an external magnetic field of 10 G. The irradiated sample exhibits a spontaneous magnetization with a T C of 40 K. The magnetization versus external magnetic field plots after irradiating for 120 min show a magnetic hysteresis loop with a H c of 12000 G at 2 K (Figure b). The magnetization value at 5 T is 7.2 μB, which suggests that CoII and WV ferromagnetically interact. The photoinduced magnetization persists for at least 1 day after turning off the light. The photoinduced magnetization relaxes to the initial value upon a thermal treatment up to 150 K, indicating that the magnetization can be increased by irradiating with light and recovered with a thermal treatment.

elements.content: (a) Field-cooled magnetization curves at 10 G and (b) magnetic hysteresis loops at 2 K; before irradiating (▴), after irradiating (□), and after thermally treating up to 150 K (○).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Field-cooled magnetization curves at 10 G and (b) magnetic hysteresis loops at 2 K; before irradiating (▴), after irradiating (□), and after thermally treating up to 150 K (○).

elements.content: The IR spectra after irradiating were measured to understand this photomagnetic behavior. Irradiating with a 840 nm laser light decreases the IR peaks due to LT phase and produces the spectra of HT phase (Supporting Information). Hence, in this photomagnetic effect, irradiating of the IT band between CoIII−WIV and CoII−WV induces a valence state change from the CoIII ls (S = 0)−WIV(S = 0) state to the CoII ls (S = 1/2)−WV(S = 1/2) state. Successively, the CoII ls (S = 1/2)−WV(S = 1/2) state changes to the CoII hs (S = 3/2)−WV(S = 1/2) state as CoII favors a high-spin state, resulting that a spontaneous magnetization appears.
elements.clean_text: The IR spectra after irradiating were measured to understand this photomagnetic behavior. Irradiating with a 840 nm laser light decreases the IR peaks due to LT phase and produces the spectra of HT phase (Supporting Information). Hence, in this photomagnetic effect, irradiating of the IT band between CoIII-WIV and CoII-WV induces a valence state change from the CoIII  ls (S = 0)-WIV(S = 0) state to the CoII  ls (S = 1/2)-WV(S = 1/2) state. Successively, the CoII  ls (S = 1/2)-WV(S = 1/2) state changes to the CoII  hs (S = 3/2)-WV(S = 1/2) state as CoII favors a high-spin state, resulting that a spontaneous magnetization appears.

elements.content: In summary, a new type of cyano-bridged Co−W bimetallic assembly was synthesized. This compound exhibited a temperature-induced phase transition with a large thermal hysteresis loop of 90 K and a photoinduced magnetization with a high T C of 40 K and a large H c of 12 000 G. These high performances are considered to be due to the octacyano-bridged 3-D network structure and the strong magnetic anisotropy of CoII.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a new type of cyano-bridged Co-W bimetallic assembly was synthesized. This compound exhibited a temperature-induced phase transition with a large thermal hysteresis loop of 90 K and a photoinduced magnetization with a high T C of 40 K and a large H c of 12000 G. These high performances are considered to be due to the octacyano-bridged 3-D network structure and the strong magnetic anisotropy of CoII.

Information relating to the crystal structure, the temperature dependence of IR spectra, the IR spectra after irradiating, and the UV−vis diffuse reflectance spectra. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The precipitated red powder was filtered and washed with water and then dried in air. A single crystal for X-ray structural analysis was prepared by a diffusion method in an H-shaped tube. cln_elements.content:
Optical functionality is an attractive issue in the field of molecule-based magnets. Photomagnetism has been observed in the photoinduced magnetization of cobalt−hexacyanoferrate, copper−octacyanomolybdate, etc. It has also been observed in the photodemagnetization of iron−hexacyanochromate and rubidium−manganese−hexacyanoferrate and in the photoinduced magnetic pole inversion of iron−manganese−hexacyanochromate. One possible method for achieving optical control of spontaneous magnetization is to change the electron spin state of a magnetic material. For example, when irradiating changes the oxidation numbers of transition metal ions in a magnetic material, its magnetization varies. From these viewpoints, octacyanometalate-based magnets are useful systems for preparing photomagnetic materials because octacyanometalates can adopt various valence states, such as WIV and WV. In this paper, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, magnetic properties, and photofunctionality of a new type of three-dimensional Co−W bimetallic assembly, CoII 3[WV(CN)8]2(pyrimidine)4·6H2O. This compound exhibits a photoinduced magnetization with a high Curie temperature (T C) of 40 K and a large coercive field (H c) of 12 000 G.

In summary, a new type of cyano-bridged Co−W bimetallic assembly was synthesized. This compound exhibited a temperature-induced phase transition with a large thermal hysteresis loop of 90 K and a photoinduced magnetization with a high T C of 40 K and a large H c of 12 000 G. These high performances are considered to be due to the octacyano-bridged 3-D network structure and the strong magnetic anisotropy of CoII.

Optical functionality is an attractive issue in the field of molecule-based magnets. Photomagnetism has been observed in the photoinduced magnetization of cobalt-hexacyanoferrate, copper-octacyanomolybdate, etc. It has also been observed in the photodemagnetization of iron-hexacyanochromate and rubidium-manganese-hexacyanoferrate and in the photoinduced magnetic pole inversion of iron-manganese-hexacyanochromate. One possible method for achieving optical control of spontaneous magnetization is to change the electron spin state of a magnetic material. For example, when irradiating changes the oxidation numbers of transition metal ions in a magnetic material, its magnetization varies. From these viewpoints, octacyanometalate-based magnets are useful systems for preparing photomagnetic materials because octacyanometalates can adopt various valence states, such as WIV and WV. In this paper, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, magnetic properties, and photofunctionality of a new type of three-dimensional Co-W bimetallic assembly, CoII 3[WV(CN)8]2(pyrimidine)4⋅6H2O. This compound exhibits a photoinduced magnetization with a high Curie temperature (T C) of 40 K and a large coercive field (H c) of 12000 G. 

In summary, a new type of cyano-bridged Co-W bimetallic assembly was synthesized. This compound exhibited a temperature-induced phase transition with a large thermal hysteresis loop of 90 K and a photoinduced magnetization with a high T C of 40 K and a large H c of 12000 G. These high performances are considered to be due to the octacyano-bridged 3-D network structure and the strong magnetic anisotropy of CoII.

metadata.title:
Photoinduced Magnetization with a High Curie Temperature and a Large
Coercive Field in a Cyano-Bridged Cobalt−Tungstate Bimetallic Assembly
